info.desc: Mark up a an interactive shell session.

page.title: Screens
page.p: Use the screen element to mark up a sequence of commands and program output from an interactive shell session. The contents of a screen element are displayed verbatim. While all inline content is allowed, input and output will frequently be used to provide richer markup inside a screen element.

item.p: The style attribute takes a space-separated list of style hints. Processing tools should adjust their behavior according to those style hints they understand.

The mime attribute takes a valid MIME type. Processing tools may adjust their behavior for particular MIME types. A MIME type is assumed to apply to the user input only; thus, processing tools may ignore the MIME type if the screen element is not composed of input and output elements.
Typical values for the mime attribute include:

tr.td: Command to execute with the Bourne shell
Command to execute with the C shell

item.p: The screen element can have attributes from external namespaces. See for more information on external-namespace attributes on inline elements.

section.title: Examples
section.p: Use screen to mark up a long command:

example.code: <screen> xsltproc -o mal_block_screen.html \ --stringparam mal.cache.file `pwd`/mallard.cache \ `pkg-config --variable mal2html gnome-doc-utils` mal_block_screen.html </screen>
example.screen: xsltproc -o mal_block_screen.html \ --stringparam mal.cache.file `pwd`/mallard.cache \ `pkg-config --variable mal2html gnome-doc-utils` mal_block_screen.html

section.p: Use input and output inside screen for richer text:

example.code: <screen> <output type="prompt">[rupert@gnome] </output><input>ls foo bar</input> <output type="error">foo: cannot access file: No such file or directory</output> <output>bar</output></screen>

screen.output: foo: cannot access file: No such file or directory

section.title: Processing Expectations
section.p: Screens should be displayed verbatim, with all whitespace and line breaks reproduced in the rendered output. The only exception is a single leading line break, which should be stripped by display tools if present.
Screens should be displayed in a fixed-width font. Inline markup may cause style variations, but they should not cause a change to a variable-width font.

section.title: Comparison to DocBook
section.p: The screen element is similar to the screen element in DocBook.
